rows.intro_text: Here's a story of a supportive father in child care.
rows.media_title: Let us listen to a story
rows.slide_1_text: Mr. Ssemakula is married with four children. He actively plays a strong role in day-to-day child-care and his wife appreciates him for his father figure involvement.
rows.slide_2_text: Whenever the wife delivers and the baby is about 2 - 3 weeks, he takes turns with his wife to carry the crying baby in the night.
rows.slide_3_text: He picks up any opportunity in his busy schedule to cuddle with his children including finding play time for out and indoor games.
rows.slide_4_text: Within their limited resources, his family seems happy and healthy. On most weekends, the family works and eats together.

rows.slide_1_text: Parents who support their children but set firm limits for them. Firm parents show high levels of warmth and control. They control the childrenâ€™s behavior by explaining rules, discussing and reasoning together. They listen to the childrenâ€™s viewpoints but do not always accept them.

Authoritarian and Strict parenting is characterisd by  High levels of control and demands on the child, poor relationships, and very strict commands coupled with low levels of love and care. Strict parents engage in low levels of communication with the children.
Permissive is charecterised by Excess love and warmth, with low levels of control. Parents do not exert control over their childrenâ€™s behavior or set limits and do not monitor their activities.
Indifferent/Uninvolve is characterised by low control and poor relationships. Parents are not interested in their children and make few demands on them.
Susan and her husband John have a troublesome son, Henry, who is 11 years old. Henry is very energetic and creative. However, he often gets into trouble at school.
rows.slide_2_text: On weekends and even on some school days, Henry escapes from home to watch movies. Susanâ€™s husband often blames her for Henryâ€™s bad behaviour saying that she spends too much time at her job, when she should be home more, watching over the children.
rows.slide_3_text: One day Susan and her husband got into a heated argument and he hit her. He often did so but this time, Susan decided that she could not take it anymore. She lashes out at Henry and beats him up, blaming him for always bringing her problems.
rows.slide_4_text: A male neighbour passed but did not say anything. As Susan contemplated leaving, she thought about her children and got discouraged, saying the children would suffer without her.

rows.intro_text:
* This activity is often implemented with men but we know that there are are families that are led by women as well. 
* Reflecting on your head, can you note down the different parts of your head and list their functions?
rows.slide_1_text:
Animation script
Person 1: let's think about different parts of the head What different parts does it have? 
Person 2: We have eyes, ears, nose , mouth , and my hair . And my brain and my face! pop up : head with the different parts of the named parts
rows.slide_2_text:
Person 1: Can we think about the different functions of the head? What are the roles and functions of the different parts we have named?
Person 2: Ok, good to go! The eyes for seeing, the mouth is for talking and eating, the nose is for smelling, the ears are for hearing, the brain is the think work, and my face gives me the identity
rows.slide_3_text: Person 1: Wow! Can we now think about our role as heads of the family? Especially in Africa, men are referred to as the heads of the family.
rows.slide_4_text: Person 1: As you reflect on the different parts of the head, for example, the eye, do you use your eyes to see opportunities that benefit your family (children and spouse) or are you using them for selfish interests? Think about your mouth, do you use it to speak to your family members or to abuse and curse them? How about your ears; do you use them to listen to them? How often. We can only take pride in family headship if we choose to function in our everyday lives for the benefit of those we live with and not for our selfish intentions. What happens if any of the parts of the head fail to function the way they are supposed to? The entire body will feel the effect? This means that if you don't utilize all our capacities and heads of our family, some members of the household will negatively be affected.
rows.outro_text: What do you learn from this activity?

rows.slide_1_text: Bosco and Esther have been married for 18 years, and they have 4 children; 3 boys and 1 girl. Every morning, Esther wakes at 5:30 am up to prepare the children for school, including organizing their breakfast.

rows.slide_3_text: While Bosco goes for his workout time (gym) Esther and the bigger children support the house helper to prepare dinner. The couples enjoys family life and yet are very instrumental in their workplaces as, they are role models to many.

rows.slide_1_text: "But I did not do anything wrong, we are just friends", Chris insisted when a family member voiced concern over the time he was spending with the girl working in the bar and restaurant. In Chrisâ€™s mind, he had not crossed any lines because there was nothing much that was happening. "I only tap her bat sometimes, just for fun, and I have no problem spending time with someone who cooks and serves us food and beer very well, daily.
rows.slide_2_text: Chris and his wife Kevin have been happily married for 7 years. But Kevin is argumentative and sometimes, an aggressive talker, who tries to win every argument. She cannot sustain a good discussion and often threatens to leave her husband because of his behaviour, especially physical and emotional violence including non-involvement in child care. Chris often feels lonely even when they are together. As a result of this, they have problems in their intimate relationships and each of them does not get sufficient intimate satisfaction (sex) but they do not talk about it. Both of them have challenges with their body hygiene including brushing, shaving, bathing, cutting nails among others. The couple has developed drinking habits to try to feel relaxed but this makes it worse as they end in fights and quarrels before the children.
rows.slide_3_text: The restaurant girl, however, is a good listener and easily reads Chrisâ€™s moods. She is quick to laugh with him and is fun to have around. As the two continued to spend time together, a friend to whom Chris had casually told about the relationship mentioned it to Kevin. When Kevin confronted Chris, he dismissed her concerns. Kevin was so disturbed and decided to fight her husband and the bar girl.

rows.slide_1_text: Doreen and the father have a good relationship characterized with love, open communication, and interactions. They do many things together including praying for each other. Along the way, Doreen gets distracted by peers who introduce her to drinking alcohol, going to parties, and gambling which draws her away from her family relationship.
rows.slide_2_text: The father tries to talk to her against these habits but she would not listen, as the other things were looking so attractive. However, rather than giving up and dis-owning his daughter, the father demonstrates a remarkable commitment to save his daughter from associated dangers.
rows.slide_3_text: He prayed persistently, went about looking for her and embraced and accepted her without being judgmental and harsh. The fatherâ€™s persistence and commitment to supporting his daughter, delivers her and she returns to their relationship.
